deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario where the source unit infects a neighbour unit.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 2 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread at 1 km is 0.808, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 25 km. These parameters give a 0.505 probability of infection at 10 km.
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.

deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario where the source unit cannot infect a neighbour unit.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 2 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread at 1 km is 0.792, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 25 km. These parameters give a 0.495 probability of infection at 10 km.
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.

deterministic-test.short-name: 2 units, just > threshold for spread, exponential
deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario where the source unit infects a neighbour unit.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 2 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread at 1 km is 0.934. This parameter gives a 0.505 probability of infection at 10 km (0.934<sup>10</sup> = 0.505).
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.

deterministic-test.short-name: 2 units, just < threshold for spread, exponential
deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario where the source unit cannot infect a neighbour unit.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 2 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread at 1 km is 0.932. This parameter gives a 0.495 probability of infection at 10 km (0.932<sup>10</sup> = 0.495).
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.

deterministic-test.short-name: 2 units, just > threshold for spread, exponential, units' locations in projected coordinates
deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario where the source unit infects a neighbour unit. This scenario is identical to "2 units, just > threshold for spread, exponential" above but the units' locations are in projected coordinates instead of latitude and longitude. This scenario plus the next one will show that the units still correctly register as 10 km apart.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 2 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread at 1 km is 0.934. This parameter gives a 0.505 probability of infection at 10 km (0.934<sup>10</sup> = 0.505).
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.

deterministic-test.short-name: 2 units, just < threshold for spread, exponential, units' locations in projected coordinates
deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario where the source unit cannot infect a neighbour unit. This scenario is identical to "2 units, just < threshold for spread, exponential" above but the units' locations are in projected coordinates instead of latitude and longitude. This scenario plus the previous one will show that the units still correctly register as 10 km apart.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 2 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread at 1 km is 0.932. This parameter gives a 0.495 probability of infection at 10 km (0.932<sup>10</sup> = 0.495).
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.

deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario where the source unit infects a neighbour unit with a 1-day airborne transport delay.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 2 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 5 days.
The probability of airborne spread at 1 km is 0.808, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 25 km. These parameters give a 0.505 probability of infection at 10 km. The airborne transport delay is 1 day.
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.

deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario where the source unit infects a neighbour unit with a 2-day airborne transport delay.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 2 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 5 days.
The probability of airborne spread at 1 km is 0.808, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 25 km. These parameters give a 0.505 probability of infection at 10 km. The airborne transport delay is 2 days.
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.

deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario where the source unit infects a neighbour unit with a 3-day airborne transport delay.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 2 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 5 days.
The probability of airborne spread at 1 km is 0.808, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 25 km. These parameters give a 0.505 probability of infection at 10 km. The airborne transport delay is 3 days.
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.

deterministic-test.short-name: 2 units, airborne spread, 1 and 2 day delay
deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario where the source unit infects one neighbour unit with a 1-day airborne transport delay and another neighbour unit with a 2-day airborne transport delay. This test failed in NAADSM version 3.2.5 and was fixed in version 3.2.6.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For all production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, the infectious clinical period lasts 2 days, and immunity lasts 5 days.
The probability of airborne spread from a sheep unit to a cattle unit at 1 km is 0.808, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 25 km. These parameters give a 0.505 probability of infection at 10 km. The airborne transport delay is 1 day.
The probability of airborne spread from a sheep unit to a pig unit at 1 km is 0.82483, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 50 km. These parameters give a 0.505 probability of infection at 20 km. The airborne transport delay is 2 days.
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.

stochastic-test.description:
Test the size factors. Use 3 units (small, medium, and large) arranged in a triangle with all sides 10 km. The size factors (2 \htmlonly × \endhtmlonly \latexonly $\times$ \endlatexonly area under size distribution from 0 to unit size) will be 1/3, 1, and 1 2/3, respectively. The small unit is initially infected.
NB: This test case does not care about secondary spread from the large unit to the medium unit or vice versa, so we end the test before that can happen.
stochastic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
stochastic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 2 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread at 1 km is 0.9, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 50 km. These parameters give a 0.41 probability of infection for a small unit and a large unit 10 km apart, and a 0.24 probability of infection for a small unit and a medium unit 10 km apart.
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.

deterministic-test.short-name: 4 units in a line, just < threshold to infect nearest
deterministic-test.description:
Test distance effects. Use 4 units, all the same size, arranged in a line with the successive units 1 km, 5 km, and 10 km from the initially infected unit.
In this test the probability of infection is just insufficient to spread to the unit at 1 km distance. The disease should not spread.
NB: This test case does not care about secondary spread, so we end the test before that can happen.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 2 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread at 1 km is 0.495, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 50 km.
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.

deterministic-test.short-name: 4 units in a line, just > threshold to infect nearest
deterministic-test.description: Run again, but with the probability of infection just sufficient to spread to the unit at 1 km distance.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 2 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread at 1 km is 0.505, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 50 km.
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.

deterministic-test.short-name: 4 units in a line, just < threshold to infect 2nd nearest
deterministic-test.description: Run again, but with the probability of infection just insufficient to spread to the unit at 5 km distance. The disease should spread to only the nearest unit.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 2 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread at 1 km is 0.539, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 50 km. These parameters give a 0.495 probability of infection at 5 km.
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.

deterministic-test.short-name: 4 units in a line, just > threshold to infect 2nd nearest
deterministic-test.description: Run again, but with the probability of infection just sufficient to spread to the unit at 5 km distance. The disease should spread to only the nearest two units.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 2 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread at 1 km is 0.55, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 50 km. These parameters give a 0.505 probability of infection at 5 km.
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.

deterministic-test.short-name: 4 units in a line, just < threshold to infect farthest
deterministic-test.description: Run again, but with the probability of infection just insufficient to spread to the unit at 10 km distance. The disease should spread to only the nearest two units.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 2 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread at 1 km is 0.606, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 50 km. These parameters give a 0.495 probability of infection at 10 km.
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.

deterministic-test.short-name: 4 units in a line, just > threshold to infect farthest
deterministic-test.description: Run again, but with the probability of infection just sufficient to spread to the unit at 10 km distance. The disease should spread to all units.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 2 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread at 1 km is 0.619, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 50 km. These parameters give a 0.505 probability of infection at 10 km.
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.

deterministic-test.description:
Test direction effects. Use a 1 km radius circle of units placed at the 12 o'clock, 1 o'clock, etc. positions around an initially infected unit in the centre.
In this test there is no wind, so no units will become infected.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 2 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread at 1 km is 0.501, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 50 km.
Permitted wind directions start at \htmlonly 0° and end at 0°. \endhtmlonly \latexonly 0$^\circ$ and end at 0$^\circ$. \endlatexonly
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.

deterministic-test.description: Run again, but with north winds (from the north). The disease should spread to units 5, 6, and 7.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 2 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread at 1 km is 0.501, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 50 km.
Permitted wind directions start at \htmlonly 135° and end at 225°. \endhtmlonly \latexonly 135$^\circ$ and end at 225$^\circ$. \endlatexonly
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.

deterministic-test.description: Run again, but with south winds (from the south). The disease should spread to units 11, 12, and 1.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 2 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread at 1 km is 0.501, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 50 km.
Permitted wind directions start at \htmlonly 315° and end at 45°. \endhtmlonly \latexonly 315$^\circ$ and end at 45$^\circ$. \endlatexonly
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.

deterministic-test.description: Run again, but with east winds (from the east). The disease should spread to units 8, 9, and 10.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 2 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread at 1 km is 0.501, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 50 km.
Permitted wind directions start at \htmlonly 225° and end at 315°. \endhtmlonly \latexonly 225$^\circ$ and end at 315$^\circ$. \endlatexonly
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.

deterministic-test.description: Run again, but with west winds (from the west). The disease should spread to units 2, 3, and 4.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 2 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread at 1 km is 0.501, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 50 km.
Permitted wind directions start at \htmlonly 45° and end at 135°. \endhtmlonly \latexonly 45$^\circ$ and end at 135$^\circ$. \endlatexonly
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.

deterministic-test.short-name: circle of units, all directions allowed
deterministic-test.description: Run again, but with the parameters set to allow spread in any direction. The disease should spread to all units.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 2 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread at 1 km is 0.501, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 50 km.
Permitted wind directions start at \htmlonly 0° and end at 360°. \endhtmlonly \latexonly 0$^\circ$ and end at 360$^\circ$. \endlatexonly
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.

deterministic-test.short-name: circle of units, source on perimeter, all directions allowed
deterministic-test.description: Run again, but with the unit at 11 o'clock as the source instead of the unit in the centre. The disease should spread to units 0, 9, 10, 12, and 1.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 2 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread at 1 km is 0.501, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 50 km.
Permitted wind directions start at \htmlonly 0° and end at 360°. \endhtmlonly \latexonly 0$^\circ$ and end at 360$^\circ$. \endlatexonly
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.

variable-test.short-name: circle of units, north wind, check reporting variables
variable-test.description: Check that the number of units infected is reported correctly. In this scenario, the same as "circle of units, north wind" above, the disease should spread to units 5, 6, and 7.
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 2 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread at 1 km is 0.501, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 50 km.
Permitted wind directions start at \htmlonly 135° and end at 225°. \endhtmlonly \latexonly 135$^\circ$ and end at 225$^\circ$. \endlatexonly
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.

deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario where airborne spread is "turned off" by setting the maximum distance of airborne spread to 0. This seems like a sensible parameter setting, but it creates a divide by zero in the formula. See whether the program handles it gracefully.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 2 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread at 1 km is 0.1, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 0 km.
Permitted wind directions start at \htmlonly 0° and end at 360°. \endhtmlonly \latexonly 0$^\circ$ and end at 360$^\circ$. \endlatexonly
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.

deterministic-test.short-name: 2 units at same location, one infected
deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario with two target units at exactly the same location. One of the target units (unit 1, cattle) should get infected; the other (unit 2, pigs) should not, even though it is at the same location.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For cattle, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 2 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days. For pigs, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness without clinical signs lasts 1 day, infectiousness with clinical signs lasts 1 day, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread from cattle to cattle at 1 km is 0.808, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 25 km. These parameters give a 0.505 probability of infection at 10 km. No parameters are set for spread from cattle to pigs.
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.

deterministic-test.short-name: 2 units at same location, other infected
deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario with two target units at exactly the same location. One of the target units (unit 2, pigs) should get infected; the other (unit 1, cattle) should not, even though it is at the same location.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For cattle, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 2 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days. For pigs, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness without clinical signs lasts 1 day, infectiousness with clinical signs lasts 1 day, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread from cattle to pigs at 1 km is 0.808, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 25 km. These parameters give a 0.505 probability of infection at 10 km. No parameters are set for spread from cattle to cattle.
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.

deterministic-test.short-name: 2 units at same location, both infected
deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario with two target units at exactly the same location. Both of the target units (pigs and cattle) should get infected.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For cattle, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 2 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days. For pigs, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness without clinical signs lasts 1 day, infectiousness with clinical signs lasts 1 day, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread from cattle to pigs at 1 km is 0.808, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 25 km. These parameters give a 0.505 probability of infection at 10 km. The parameters for spread from cattle to cattle are the same.
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.

deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario where there is no quarantine. An infectious unit should continue to infect neighbour units after detection.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For pigs (unit 1), the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness without clinical signs lasts 1 day, infectiousness with clinical signs lasts 6 days, and immunity lasts 2 days. For cattle (unit 0), the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 1 day, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 0 days.
These parameters cause the cattle to be infected, recover, and be re-infected repeatedly.
The probability of airborne spread from pigs to cattle at 1 km is 0.808, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 25 km. These parameters give a 0.505 probability of infection at 10 km when used with fixed "random" numbers of 0.5. No parameters are set for spread from cattle to pigs.
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.

variable-test.description: Test that the number of infections is reported correctly when a unit is infected repeatedly. In this scenario, the same as "no quarantine" above, an infectious unit repeatedly re-infects a neighbour unit.
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
For pigs (unit 1), the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness without clinical signs lasts 1 day, infectiousness with clinical signs lasts 6 days, and immunity lasts 2 days. For cattle (unit 0), the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 1 day, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 0 days.
These parameters cause the cattle to be infected, recover, and be re-infected repeatedly.
The probability of airborne spread from pigs to cattle at 1 km is 0.808, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 25 km. These parameters give a 0.505 probability of infection at 10 km when used with fixed "random" numbers of 0.5. No parameters are set for spread from cattle to pigs.
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.

deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario where there is quarantine. Quarantine does not affect airborne spread, so an infectious unit should continue to infect neighbour units after detection.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For pigs (unit 1), the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness without clinical signs lasts 1 day, infectiousness with clinical signs lasts 6 days, and immunity lasts 2 days. For cattle (unit 0), the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 1 day, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 0 days.
These parameters cause the cattle to be infected, recover, and be re-infected repeatedly.
The probability of airborne spread from pigs to cattle at 1 km is 0.808, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 25 km. These parameters give a 0.505 probability of infection at 10 km when used with fixed "random" numbers of 0.5. No parameters are set for spread from cattle to pigs.
The probability of detection vs. the number of days a pig unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1. No parameters are set for detection of cattle units.
The authorities require 4 days to set up a destruction program before beginning. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
There is no vaccination.

deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario where there is quarantine. Quarantine does not affect airborne spread, so an infectious unit should continue to infect neighbour units after detection.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For pigs (unit 1), the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness without clinical signs lasts 1 day, infectiousness with clinical signs lasts 6 days, and immunity lasts 2 days. For cattle (unit 0), the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 1 day, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 0 days.
These parameters cause the cattle to be infected, recover, and be re-infected repeatedly.
The probability of airborne spread from pigs to cattle at 1 km is 0.808, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 25 km. These parameters give a 0.505 probability of infection at 10 km when used with fixed "random" numbers of 0.5. No parameters are set for spread from cattle to pigs.
The probability of detection is 0.4 when a pig unit first shows clinical signs. It remains at 0.4 for 1 day, then increases linearly to 0.6 for the next day. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is fixed at 1. No parameters are set for detection of cattle units.
The authorities require 2 days to set up a destruction program before beginning. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
There is no vaccination.

deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario where 2 infected units both infect the same target on the same day. This is a baseline where just the source below the target infects.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For sheep and cattle (units 0 and 1), the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 1 day, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 2 days. For pigs (unit 2), the latent period lasts 1 day, then the unit immediately returns to Susceptible.
The probability of airborne spread from sheep to cattle at 1 km is 0.808, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 25 km. These parameters give a 0.505 probability of infection at 10 km when used with fixed "random" numbers of 0.5. No parameters are set for spread between any other combination of production types.
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On day 1 units 0 (sheep) and 2 (pigs) will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 0 will become infectious and will infect unit 1 (cattle) via airborne spread. Unit 2 will go back to Susceptible. - On day 3 the newly-infected unit 1 will be Latent.

variable-test.short-name: infection from 2 sources, just 1st source, check reporting variables
variable-test.description: Test a scenario where 2 infected units both infect the same target on the same day, and thus double-counting of a single infection might occur. This scenario, the same as "infection from 2 sources, just 1st source" above, is a baseline where just the source below the target infects.
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
For sheep and cattle (units 0 and 1), the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 1 day, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 2 days. For pigs (unit 2), the latent period lasts 1 day, then the unit immediately returns to Susceptible.
The probability of airborne spread from sheep to cattle at 1 km is 0.808, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 25 km. These parameters give a 0.505 probability of infection at 10 km when used with fixed "random" numbers of 0.5. No parameters are set for spread between any other combination of production types.
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On day 1 units 0 (sheep) and 2 (pigs) will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 0 will become infectious and will infect unit 1 (cattle) via airborne spread. Unit 2 will go back to Susceptible. - On day 3 the newly-infected unit 1 will be Latent.

deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario where 2 infected units both infect the same target on the same day. This is a baseline where just the source above the target infects.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For cattle and pigs (units 1 and 2), the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 1 day, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 2 days. For sheep (unit 0), the latent period lasts 1 day, then the unit immediately returns to Susceptible.
The probability of airborne spread from pigs to cattle at 1 km is 0.808, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 25 km. These parameters give a 0.505 probability of infection at 10 km when used with fixed "random" numbers of 0.5. No parameters are set for spread between any other combination of production types.
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On day 1 units 0 (sheep) and 2 (pigs) will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 2 will become infectious and will infect unit 1 (cattle) via airborne spread. Unit 0 will go back to Susceptible. - On day 3 the newly-infected unit 1 will be Latent.

variable-test.short-name: infection from 2 sources, just 2nd source, check reporting variables
variable-test.description: Test a scenario where 2 infected units both infect the same target on the same day, and thus double-counting of a single infection might occur. This scenario, the same as "infection from 2 sources, just 2nd source" above, is a baseline where just the source above the target infects.
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
For cattle and pigs (units 1 and 2), the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 1 day, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 2 days. For sheep (unit 0), the latent period lasts 1 day, then the unit immediately returns to Susceptible.
The probability of airborne spread from pigs to cattle at 1 km is 0.808, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 25 km. These parameters give a 0.505 probability of infection at 10 km when used with fixed "random" numbers of 0.5. No parameters are set for spread between any other combination of production types.
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On day 1 units 0 (sheep) and 2 (pigs) will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 2 will become infectious and will infect unit 1 (cattle) via airborne spread. Unit 0 will go back to Susceptible. - On day 3 the newly-infected unit 1 will be Latent.

deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario where 2 infected units both infect the same target on the same day.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For all production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 1 day, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 2 days.
The probability of airborne spread from sheep or pigs to cattle at 1 km is 0.808, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 25 km. These parameters give a 0.505 probability of infection at 10 km when used with fixed "random" numbers of 0.5. No parameters are set for spread from sheep to pigs, from pigs to sheep, or from cattle to any other type.
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On day 1 units 0 (sheep) and 2 (pigs) will be Latent. - On day 2 units 0 and 2 will become infectious and will both attempt to infect unit 1 (cattle) via airborne spread. - On day 3 the newly-infected unit 1 will be Latent.

variable-test.short-name: infection from 2 sources, check reporting variables
variable-test.description: Test a scenario where 2 infected units both infect the same target on the same day, and thus double-counting of a single infection might occur. In this scenario, the same as "infection from 2 sources" above, 2 infected units both infect the same target on the same day.
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
For all production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 1 day, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 2 days.
The probability of airborne spread from sheep or pigs to cattle at 1 km is 0.808, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 25 km. These parameters give a 0.505 probability of infection at 10 km when used with fixed "random" numbers of 0.5. No parameters are set for spread from sheep to pigs, from pigs to sheep, or from cattle to any other type.
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On day 1 units 0 (sheep) and 2 (pigs) will be Latent. - On day 2 units 0 and 2 will become infectious and will both attempt to infect unit 1 (cattle) via airborne spread. - On day 3 the newly-infected unit 1 will be Latent.

deterministic-test.description: This is one of 4 scenarios that tests applying different parameters to different production type combinations. In this scenario, the probability of spread is not high enough to infect either possible target.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For all production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 1 day, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread from sheep to cattle at 1 km is 0.6064, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 50 km. These parameters give a 0.495 probability of infection at 10 km when used with fixed "random" numbers of 0.5. The probability of airborne spread from sheep to pigs at 1 km is 0.8085, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 50 km. These parameters give a 0.495 probability of infection at 20 km when used with fixed "random" numbers of 0.5. No parameters are set for spread from any other combination of production types.
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On day 1 unit 0 (sheep) will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 0 will be infectious. It will not be able to infect either of the other 2 units via airborne spread.

deterministic-test.description: This is one of 4 scenarios that tests applying different parameters to different production type combinations. In this scenario, the probability of spread is high enough to infect one possible target but not the other.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For all production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 1 day, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread from sheep to cattle at 1 km is 0.6186, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 50 km. These parameters give a 0.505 probability of infection at 10 km when used with fixed "random" numbers of 0.5. The probability of airborne spread from sheep to pigs at 1 km is 0.8085, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 50 km. These parameters give a 0.495 probability of infection at 20 km when used with fixed "random" numbers of 0.5. No parameters are set for spread from any other combination of production types.
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On day 1 unit 0 (sheep) will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 0 will be infectious. It will infect unit 1 (cattle) via airborne spread, but will not be able to infect unit 2. - On day 3 unit 1 will be Latent.

deterministic-test.description: This is one of 4 scenarios that tests applying different parameters to different production type combinations. In this scenario, the probability of spread is high enough to infect one possible target but not the other.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For all production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 1 day, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread from sheep to cattle at 1 km is 0.6064, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 50 km. These parameters give a 0.495 probability of infection at 10 km when used with fixed "random" numbers of 0.5. The probability of airborne spread from sheep to pigs at 1 km is 0.8248, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 50 km. These parameters give a 0.505 probability of infection at 20 km when used with fixed "random" numbers of 0.5. No parameters are set for spread from any other combination of production types.
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On day 1 unit 0 (sheep) will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 0 will be infectious. It will infect unit 2 (pigs) via airborne spread, but will not be able to infect unit 1. - On day 3 unit 2 will be Latent.

deterministic-test.description: This is one of 4 scenarios that tests applying different parameters to different production type combinations. In this scenario, the probability of spread is high enough to infect both possible targets.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For all production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 1 day, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread from sheep to cattle at 1 km is 0.6186, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 50 km. These parameters give a 0.505 probability of infection at 10 km when used with fixed "random" numbers of 0.5. The probability of airborne spread from sheep to pigs at 1 km is 0.8248, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 50 km. These parameters give a 0.505 probability of infection at 20 km when used with fixed "random" numbers of 0.5. No parameters are set for spread from any other combination of production types.
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On day 1 unit 0 (sheep) will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 0 will be infectious. It will infect unit 1 (cattle) and unit 2 (pigs) via airborne spread. - On day 3 units 1 and 2 will be Latent.

deterministic-test.description: Test that prevalence influences the probability of airborne spread. In this baseline scenario, the default prevalence (1.0 for the entire duration of the disease) is used.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description: The latent period lasts 3 days, infectiousness lasts 3 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days. The probability of airborne spread at 1 km is 0.9, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 25 km. Permitted wind directions start at \htmlonly 45° and end at 135° \endhtmlonly \latexonly 45$^\circ$ and end at 135$^\circ$ \endlatexonly (i.e., wind is from the west). With prevalence at 1.0, these parameters give a >0.5 probability of spread at 1 km, 5 km, and 10 km. There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction. Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On days 1-3 unit 0 will be Latent. - On day 4 unit 0 will become infectious and will infect units 1, 2, and 3 via airborne spread. - On day 5 units 1, 2, and 3 will be Latent.

deterministic-test.description: Test that prevalence influences the probability of airborne spread. In this scenario, the prevalence increases so that the infection can spread farther on each day.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description: The latent period lasts 3 days, infectiousness lasts 3 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days. The probability of airborne spread at 1 km is 0.9, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 25 km. Permitted wind directions start at \htmlonly 45° and end at 135° \endhtmlonly \latexonly 45$^\circ$ and end at 135$^\circ$ \endlatexonly (i.e., wind is from the west). The prevalence is high enough to infect a unit 1 km away on the first day of the Infectious Clinical period, high enough to infect a unit 5 km away on the second day, and high enough to infect a unit 10 km away on the third day. There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction. Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On days 1-3 unit 0 will be Latent. - On day 4 unit 0 will become infectious. The prevalence (0.6) will be high enough that unit 1 will be infected by airborne spread. - On day 5 unit 1 will be Latent. Unit 0's prevalence (0.75) will be high enough that unit 2 will be infected by airborne spread. - On day 6 unit 2 will be Latent. Unit 0's prevalence (1.0) will be high enough that unit 3 will be infected by airborne spread. - On day 7 unit 0's infectious period will be over. Unit 3 will be Latent. - On day 8 and forward units 1, 2, and 3 will go through their infectious stages, but there will be no opportunities for them to spread infection.
